attributes.alt: Book cover for A House in the Sky by Steve Jenkins. The cover shows a bird flying in the sky above a turtle surrounded by flowers and greenery.

elements.text: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes
Use Circle Time to introduce the letters
, engage children with a movement activity, and introduce vocabulary words
What are some animal homes that animals can live in?
Use information to describe; Use information to categorize.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Encourage children to identify the sounds /w/ and /eks/.
What is it like where animals live?
What is one animal in that book? Where does that animal live?
What animal will you pretend to be? How will you get home?
Can you name three animal homes?
Can you draw a picture of an animal in its home?
What materials can you use to make an animal home?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to make an animal home?

Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder Identify and Solve Problems and introduce vocabulary

Read closely and then talk about how animals solve their problems of finding a home.

What is it like where animals live?
Can you find an animal home in the book?

attributes.alt: Book cover for A House in the Sky by Steve Jenkins. The cover shows a bird flying in the sky above a turtle surrounded by flowers and greenery.

elements.text: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes
Use Circle Time to build background about anial homes, engage children with a song, and introduce the vocabulary
Why are different homes good for different animals?
Check understanding, and differentiate as needed.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Help children identify an animal home in a picture and tell what animals might live there.
What is it like where animals live?
How are some animal homes the same? How are they different?
Can you show me your animal home? Where do you live?
Which is bigger: a nest or a cave?
Write about an animal family in their animal home.
Make an animal house using play clay. What animal home will you create?
Find the letter at the beginning of the word
Can you make an animal home for your favorite animal?

attributes.alt:
A chart titled At the Pond. The chart shows different types of animals in and around a pond within a forest.
The animals include fish, grasshoppers, ducks, a frog, rabbits, birds, deer, a butterfly, and a fox.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about animal homes, engage children with a mime activity, and  introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to make a connection with the concept question:
What is it like where animals live?
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Use digital learning applications and programs.
Guide children to discuss animals that live at the pond.
Invite children to identify what makes a pond a great home for some animals.
What is it like where animals live?
Can you make a rhyme with a word you see in your book?
Pretend to be one of the animals that live at the pond. What part of the pond do you live in?
Draw the pond. How many worms can you draw in the dirt?
Pretend you are visiting the pond and see all of these animals. Can you write about your day?
Can you create an animal home we learn about in “At the Pond”? What materials will you use?
? Can you draw things that have the letter
Can you build an animal home we learn about in “At the Pond”?

attributes.alt: Book cover for A House in the Sky by Steve Jenkins. The cover shows a bird flying in the sky above a turtle surrounded by flowers and greenery.

elements.text: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes
Use Circle Time to actively engage children and introduce vocabulary.
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking:
Which animal would you be? Where would you live?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding, and differentiate as needed.
Share and repeat details in a text.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Pretend you live in one of the animal homes in the book. What’s life like in your animal home?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What is it like where animals live?
If you wrote your own book about an animal home, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend you live in an animal home? How will you tell your parents what you need?
Can you name five animals that live at the pond?
Can you write a story about an animal home?
What materials can you use to make your own home?
Can you find things that start with the /w/ sound?
Can you build the pond where many animals live?
